content: If I put recipient it puts my name. I'm trying to get it to list the second line of "from" the actual email address.
creator: ronrobert

content:
There is no "actual email address" column. Noe is it a second line. An email address in an email has the parts of "Display Name" followed by the email address. The following is such for an email from this forum.

Thunderbird by default replaces the recipient information as well as the sender with available information from the address book. It is considered "more friendly" but it is easily disabled in the settings.

What is not so easily disabled is Thunderbird's penchant to only display the display name in list views. Hence these feedback topics in the feedback and ideas site. https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/new-column-for-e-mail-address-of-sender/idi-p/38300 https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/show-full-email-address-when-mouse-over-sender/idi-p/29010

Perhaps you might like to participate or vote for the ideas.

creator: shopov.bogomil

content:
Hello,

The error message you’re encountering indicates that the recipient’s email server has rejected the email address pgbentley101@gmail.com. This can happen for several reasons:

  • Non-Existent Email Address: The email address might not exist, or there could be a typo in the address. Double-check the email address for any errors.
  • DNS Problem: If this error occurs with every email you try to send, it could be a DNS issue. Clearing your DNS cache might resolve the problem.
  • Anti-Spam Filter: The recipient’s email server may have marked your email as spam. In this case, the recipient needs to whitelist your email address.
  • DBEB Blocking: If you’re using Microsoft 365 and sending emails to public folders, Directory Based Edge Blocking (DBEB) might be preventing the emails from being delivered. Ensure that the public folders are hosted on-premise.

To troubleshoot, start by ensuring the email address is correct and try sending the email again. If the problem persists, consider the other the possibilities mentioned above.

Best Regard, Ryan Manus CoveredCalifornia

content: The addressbook is in the root of the profile folder, and name is abook.sqlite. You can locate it by this: - help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open profile' -the abook.sqlite file is in the folder you are now viewing. There may be others, such as abook-1.sqlite. Ignore any of those. - if you collect addresses from senders, they will be in the history.sqlite file.

content:
David (and colleagues):

I have cracked the code on filters. It was confused by my having multiple email accounts and filters for each. The nexus of the problem was my lack of understanding of how and when they are applied, and the results that TB displays.

If you create filters, they must be specific to the inbox of each separate account, a fact that really belongs in the web page you sent me to. TB WILL let you create what appear to be global filters, but they won't work, and if you are in your main inbox and issue Tools/Message Filters you will see them all, but no linkage is described as to which account owns which filters. That is also why if you try to "Run Now" nothing will happen, because naturally the filter "expects" to see mail in the inbox of that particular email account.

This was my lack of understanding. Once I figured out that filters are relevant only to a specific inbox of a specific email account and I defined those filters correctly (as David pointed out), THEN THEY WORK.

David, THANK YOU!

content: First, to clarify some terms, you have POP and IMAP backwards: POP downloads and deletes from server; IMAP allows shared access across phone and PC. To keep locally, you can create a filter to select by date and copy to local folder.

content: Assuming you use Windows, you might look in c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles to see if any content is there. Messages would be in either the Mail folder or the Imapmail folder within one of the profile folders. But it's probably gone.

creator: tammyallsup

content: Okay, this may be a waste of time, but worth a check. In thunderbird, click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder' on left side, and click 'open folder'. You are now in the profile. If the account was a POP account, any residual info will be in the Mail folder or the Mail\Local Folders folder. Look for the account name. If IMAP, look in the Imapmail folder. If you see folders that look possible, such as inbox & inbox.msf, you may have found some messages. If you find anything of interest, we can go to next step.

content:
I largely stopped reading when I got to

Currently I receive the following message: "Did not connect: Potential Security Issue" "Thunderbird detected a potential security threat and did not continue to accounts.google.com because the website requires a secure connection." (I get one of these messages for each Gmail account).

This is almost invariably an issue with an antivirus program attempting to scan email using self signed encryption certificates (SSL/TLS) that Thunderbird does not allow unless you manually create exceptions for them. The simple solution is disallow the email a scanning. The more difficult solution is to follow the antivirus vendors instruction on how to make their self signed certificates trusted by Thunderbird for encryption.

However Defender does not play those games as it does not scan email.

Perhaps open the error console. (ctrl+shift+J) Clear it using the trash can icon in the left corner of its toolbar and then try and get mail for one of the accounts. The errors may offer something more useful that what we have now as your issue sounds like something from a VPN or antivirus, not normal system stuff.

Note there is a right click menu ion the console to allow you to copy all the messages if you want to copy and paste to share them or save them.
creator: MattAuSupport
